momken tedawar 3ala case study about france gov. moving from open source to MS application to reduce cost, it was great analysis but this is  3-4 years old one. for the reply why it is more expensive, I will reply in details tomorrow.

Mahmoud Magdy
3-4 years ago !!

انا دورت على حاجه زى كده بخصوص الحكومه الفرنسيه بس طلعلى ده

French Prime Minister Jean-Marc Ayrault has issued a missive to French ministers, including a complete action plan urging government usage of LibreOffice and PostgreSQL. But the action plan calls for more. As noted on Slashdot: "He also wants them to reinvest between 5 percent and 10 percent of the money they save through not paying for proprietary software licenses, spending it instead on contributing to the development of the free software. The administration already submits patches and bug fixes for the applications it uses, but Ayrault wants to go beyond that, contributing to or paying for the addition of new functionality to the software."

وده كان فى شهر سبتمبر اللى فات !!
mozhra 3shan al open source xD gdeeda xD

Well, I know that my response might raise a fight, but there is a very important fact to highlight, there is no right or wrong, nor better or best, the good architect always say "it depends" , so what might fit for a company might not fit for the other, so the open source argument has been discussed for years, and through my consulting life I visited a lot of companies and enterprises (gov, financials, real estate..etc), and on every company that tried to adopt that open source there was 3 main areas that put the initiative to fail (1) lack of support, (2) lack of expertise, (3) assuming the open source is totally free which is not, I was in RedHat conference that was done earlier this year, RedHat tells you we are open source bla bla bla, but to get updates and to get support you have to pay, and this is where the catch lies beneath, you have to pay something to get another something, I have seen a hall project in a very and I mean it VERY large enterprise where we wanted  to do voice integration with astrisk (we were using Lync), we were able to finish in less than 5 days, for them to configure something in astrisk they didn't know how to do it and they spent 2 weeks trying to figure it out, so they are using opensource product, yes, free yes, but there is a fact that we never measure because the labor is cheap, we don't measure the operations cost, but it is huge in this case, in the mean time, i believe that some industries heavily rely on Linux like telco, factories and some banking areas, but in Egypt, el nas fakra eno kol 7aga b balash, but try to standardize your infrastructure and do proper operations...you will not as simple as it is.

While you can upgrade to Windows 8 for less than $100 or sometimes less than $50, if you want to buy a "reliable" enterprise-ready edition of Ubuntu, you pay $105-165, as per http://www.ubuntu.com/business/desktop#professional-support-from-the-experts
Wallahi mesh mas2alet di bas , let us see the effort that MS did in universities and how they work hard to develop the younger generation, what did red hat do

it's good that they buy commercial Operating System because if something happen they can demand Microsoft in court but if linux crashed who they will demand? this is the strategy of commercial softwares in General. for some reasons they are better than Open source in terms of Enterprise services.
you can pay for what Red Hat Call it (subscription) auh so you don't buy the OS god forbid, you pay for the "Subscription" which is good thing
